newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia's Mahathir defends Jackson concert.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia's Mahathir defends Jackson concert.

text.p: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said on Thursday he had allowed a Michael Jackson concert in Kuala Lumpur to give Malaysians the chance to watch a "star in action", the national Bernama news agency reported.

"We are giving fans a chance to watch a live performance of the famous entertainer," Mahathir said of the concert to be held this weekend. "It is never our intention to label anything as bad because it is up to us to make our own assessment as to what is good or bad."
But he warned fans to behave or they would miss out on future concerts.
"If it is out of control, it will be the last time we give our consent," he said.
The concert's organisers, Jojo Entertainment, said on Thursday that Jackson would give a second show on Tuesday.
Mahathir's unusual defence came after weeks of controversy in Malaysia over the concert by the U.S. pop star, who last year settled a suit out of court alleging child abuse.

Jackson was originally scheduled to perform in central Selangor state bordering Kuala Lumpur but local authorities abruptly cancelled the show two weeks ago, saying the singer could have "undesirable effects" on Malaysian youth.
On Tuesday a pro-Islamic youth movement threatened to get a court injuction to stop the show, which has been sold out.

Mahathir said his government was also concerned about morality but defended Jackson: "Even if we do not watch (him) but still look at pornographic books or materials over the Internet... do we need to impose a ban on the Internet?"
